meta.content: Microfluidics and Nanofluidics 2017 21:8
meta.name: dc.source

meta.content: 2017 Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany
meta.name: dc.copyright

meta.content: In the present study, the purification and extraction of five chemical warfare agent (CWA) simulants, dimethyl methyl phosphonate, di(propylene glycol) methyl ether, methyl salicylate, triethyl phosphate, and diethyl phthalate, on a digital microfluidic (DMF) device were demonstrated. The DMF on-chip purification and extraction was performed using a magnetic bead (MB)-based diol solid-phase extraction procedure. The extracted CWA simulants were detected using both matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). The method detection limits of the DMF-MS approach using diol-MBs were also determined. In particular, for the DMF-GC-MS, the quantitative analysis ability was validated by determining accuracy, precision, calibration curve performance, and recovery efficiency. This study clearly shows that the CWA analyses can be automated on the DMF-MS platform, thereby minimizing human involvement.

meta.content: Sample preparation of chemical warfare agent simulants on a digital microfluidic (DMF) device using magnetic bead-based solid-phase extraction - Microfluidics and Nanofluidics

In the present study, the purification and extraction of five chemical warfare agent (CWA) simulants, dimethyl methyl phosphonate, di(propylene glycol) methyl ether, methyl salicylate, triethyl phosphate, and diethyl phthalate, on a digital microfluidic (DMF) device were demonstrated. The DMF on-chip purification and extraction was performed using a magnetic bead (MB)-based diol solid-phase extraction procedure. The extracted CWA simulants were detected using both matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). The method detection limits of the DMF-MS approach using diol-MBs were also determined. In particular, for the DMF-GC-MS, the quantitative analysis ability was validated by determining accuracy, precision, calibration curve performance, and recovery efficiency. This study clearly shows that the CWA analyses can be automated on the DMF-MS platform, thereby minimizing human involvement.

div.div: Sample preparation of chemical warfare agent simulants on a digital microfluidic (DMF) device using magnetic bead-based solid-phase extraction

header.h1: Sample preparation of chemical warfare agent simulants on a digital microfluidic (DMF) device using magnetic bead-based solid-phase extraction
header.p:
Microfluidics and Nanofluidics
volume
21
, Article number:
141
(
2017
)
Cite this article

li.p:
664
Accesses

4
Citations

div.p: In the present study, the purification and extraction of five chemical warfare agent (CWA) simulants, dimethyl methyl phosphonate, di(propylene glycol) methyl ether, methyl salicylate, triethyl phosphate, and diethyl phthalate, on a digital microfluidic (DMF) device were demonstrated. The DMF on-chip purification and extraction was performed using a magnetic bead (MB)-based diol solid-phase extraction procedure. The extracted CWA simulants were detected using both matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). The method detection limits of the DMF-MS approach using diol-MBs were also determined. In particular, for the DMF-GC-MS, the quantitative analysis ability was validated by determining accuracy, precision, calibration curve performance, and recovery efficiency. This study clearly shows that the CWA analyses can be automated on the DMF-MS platform, thereby minimizing human involvement.

Chemical warfare agents (CWAs), which are extremely toxic and lethal chemicals, are considered as a potential threat that can possibly lead to mass destruction, along with biological warfare agents (BWAs) (Ganesa et al.
2010
). Based on distinct physicochemical, physiological, and chemical properties, there are several types of CWAs such as nerve agents, blistering agents, cyanogenic agents, pulmonary agents, tear agents, psychomimetic agents, and toxins (Ganesa et al.
2010
). CWAs can be disseminated in a variety of forms (e.g., gas, liquid, and aerosol). Since the use of CWAs in World War I, international efforts to prevent the use of CWAs and BWAs have continuously been made (Sims
1983
; Geissler
1986
; Technical Secretariat of Organization for Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
1997
; Eubanks et al.
2007
; Kim et al.
2011
). Nonetheless, their relatively simple and inexpensive production compared with other formidable weapons has made CWAs attractive weapons for terrorist tactics and military actions. Such existing and potential threats of CWAs have led to the development of methods and devices for rapidly and reliably detecting and identifying CWAs (Murray and Southard
2002
; Black and Muir
2003
; Hook et al.
2003
; Kim et al.
2011
; Pragney and Vijaya Saradhi
2012
).

Over the last decade, a digital microfluidics (DMF) device based on the “
electrowetting
-
on
-
dielectrics
(
EWOD
)” principle has emerged as a versatile platform for chemical and biological analyses (Pollack et al.
2000
; Cho et al.
2003
; Mugele and Baret
2005
; Choi et al.
2012
; Shamsi et al.
2015
). In the DMF device, a hydrophilic droplet can be manipulated electrostatically, in a (digitized) discontinuous fashion, on an array of the electrodes covered with an insulator and a hydrophobic surface. On the DMF chip, a variety of droplet manipulations, such as dispensing, transporting, splitting, merging, and mixing, can also be readily implemented, even simultaneously, by applying a sequence of electric pulses to the array of the electrodes (Pollack et al.
2000
). Facile control of the electric pulses, and thus the droplet movements, has enabled the application of the DMF technology to many important biological, medical, and chemical processes. To name a few, PCR (polymerase chain reaction) and immunoassays are notable examples in which the use of a DMF device has been successfully demonstrated (Chang et al.
2006
; Hua et al.
2010
; Miller et al.
2011
; Ng et al.
2012
; Choi et al.
2013
; Kaler and Prakash
2014
; Shamsi et al.
2014
). Another notable advantage of the DMF technology lies in the small volume of liquids, often less than 1 μL, used in handling digitized droplets (Choi et al.
2012
). Thus, this feature renders the DMF device an attractive analytical platform for sensitive detection of analytes existing only in small quantities. Further, the DMF device combined with mass spectrometry (MS) has been demonstrated for the identifications of peptides and small molecules such as testosterone and estrogen (Moon et al.
2006
; Mousa et al.
2009
; Jebrail et al.
2009
; Luk et al.
2012
; Kirby and Wheeler
2013a
,
b
; Liu et al.
2015
; Jang et al.
2017
). These studies demonstrated that when a DMF device was coupled with MS, it could provide a sensitive and automated analytical platform for the analysis of a small amount of analyte. In this format, i.e., DMF-MS, a DMF chip acted as the device for sample preparation. In this vein, DMF-MS can also be utilized for the analysis of CWAs.

For CWA analysis in the DMF-MS platform, a CWA purification and extraction procedure on the DMF chip is necessary. In this regard, solid-phase extraction (SPE) offers an attractive method (Murray and Southard
2002
; Hook et al.
2003
). In general, SPE is a sample preparation procedure widely used for the purification, enrichment, and extraction of a certain family of chemicals and biological species in liquid mixtures such as water, urine, blood, food, soil, and beverages through molecular interactions between desired analytes and a solid-state stationary material (Hennion
1999
; August et al.
2013
). In SPE, a variety of sorbent materials have been introduced for the selective and specific enrichment and extraction of targeted analytes. A few notable efforts to incorporate SPE into a DMF chip have been made toward the efficient purification and enrichment of certain target molecules (Yang et al.
2011
; Mudrik et al.
2014
; Lafreniere et al.
2015
). For example, a high-porosity polymer material was used for the selective purification of proteins and peptides (Yang et al.
2011
; Mudrik et al.
2014
). More interestingly, magnetic beads (MBs) coated with specific functional groups have been introduced for the same purpose (Lafreniere et al.
2015
). In recent years, MPs with surfaces coated with a variety of functional groups have been developed and made commercially available. Thus, it is now possible to readily implement a variety of MPs with specific functional groups into the DMF technology.

In this study, we demonstrate that five CWA simulants (structures shown in Scheme
1
) can be readily analyzed on the DMF-MS platform; CWAs could likely also be detected with some modifications to the analytical procedure or material. For safety purposes, CWA simulants, which have a lowered toxicity and are readily available, are often used instead of CWAs (Kim et al.
2011
). Samples were prepared using a MB-based SPE, in which MBs were coated with diol-functional groups. MS analysis was performed using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) MS and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). GC-MS has been widely used for the detection of CWAs (Murray and Southard
2002
; Black and Muir
2003
; Hook et al.
2003
; Kim et al.
2011
), and in recent years, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) has been shown to a very powerful tool for the rapid detection and identification of microorganisms, particularly BWAs, thus becoming one of the requisite tools in a military laboratory (Van Ert et al.
2004
; Saffert et al.
2011
; Jeong et al.
2013
). In emergency situations, particularly in a mobile laboratory, minimizing human involvement through automation is very important due to space and personnel limitations. (However, it should be mentioned that the use of MALDI-TOF mass spectrometer is very limited in a small-scale military mobile laboratory, due to its size and the stability issue related to the operation.) Therefore, this study is expected to lead to the potential use of DMF technology in the detection and identification of chemical and biological warfare agents.

Nerve gas simulant structures:
A
DMMP (dimethyl methylphosphonate),
B
DPGME (di(propylene glycol) methyl ether),
C
TEP (triethyl phosphate),
D
MeSA (methyl salicylate), and
E
DEP (diethyl phthalate)

α-Cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid (CHCA), 1-propanol, and trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) were purchased from Sigma (St. Louis, MO, USA). CWA (nerve gas) simulants [dimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP, vapor pressure: 0.962 mmHg at 25 °C), di(propylene glycol) methyl ether (DPGME, vapor pressure: 0.375 mmHg at 25 °C), methyl salicylate (MeSA, vapor pressure: 0.0343 mmHg at 25 °C), triethyl phosphate (TEP, vapor pressure: 0.177 mmHg at 25 °C), and diethyl phthalate (DEP, vapor pressure: 0.002 mmHg at 25 °C)] were provided by the Agency for Defense Development (Daejeon, Korea). Acetonitrile (ACN) and water of HPLC grade were obtained from Thermo Fisher Scientific (San Jose, CA, USA), and ethyl acetate (EA) was acquired from Duksan Pure Chemicals (Seoul, Korea). Diol-MBs (250 nm size, silica-fortified dextran–iron oxide composite particles) were purchased from Micromod (Rostock, Germany). A neodymium rare earth magnet (15.9 mm diameter × 6.4 mm thickness, pull force of 15.3 lb) was purchased from APEX Magnets (Petersburg, WV, USA). Sep-pak C
18
cartridges (1 mL, 60 mg) and Oasis HLB (hydrophilic lipophilic balance) cartridges (1 mL, 60 mg) were obtained from Waters (Milford, MA, USA). Carbograph cartridges (1 mL, 60 mg) were purchased from Grace Alltech (Columbia, MD, USA). Diol cartridges (HyperSep; column capacity, 1 mL; bed weight, 50 mg) were obtained from Thermo Fisher Scientific (Waltham, MA, USA). A solid-phase microextraction (SPME) manual sampling holder and 75 μm fiber (carboxen/polydimethylsiloxane) were purchased from Supelco (Bellefonte, PA, USA).

Two-plate DMF chips were fabricated for this study. The bottom plate was fabricated using GIST facilities. The fabrication details are as follows. Glass slides (74 mm × 56 mm, Dongsung, Gwangju, Korea) were sonicated with distilled water, acetone, and isopropanol for 10 min each and dried by nitrogen blowing. Metal electrodes were patterned on pre-cleaned substrates via conventional photolithography. Hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS, AZ Promoter-K, Microchem) as an adhesion layer was coated on the cleaned glass slide using a spin coater (ACE-200, DONG AH Trade Corp., Seoul, Korea). Subsequently, a positive photoresist (GXR601, Microchem) was spin-coated and then exposed to UV light using a mask aligner system (CA-6 M, Shinumst, Daejeon, Korea). It was developed in MIF 300 (Microchem, MA, USA), rinsed with distilled water, and dried by nitrogen blowing. Cr (3 nm)/Au (100 nm) layers as an interdigitated electrode were thermally evaporated on the photoresist-patterned substrates using a thermal evaporator (GVTE-1000-11T, GV tech, Daejeon, Korea), and then residual photoresist was completely lifted off using acetone. This bottom plate was rinsed with methanol and dried by nitrogen blowing. Ethanol was sprayed onto the bottom plate, which was then immediately fitted with a 15-μm-thick PVDC film (polyvinylidene chloride, Saran food wrap), which acted as an insulating layer. This thin film was previously referred to as the “
skin
” (Yang et al.
2009
). This PVDC-fitted plate was annealed at 75 °C for 2 min in an oven. This plate was then coated with 50 nm of Teflon-AF (2% w/v, 2000 rpm, 60 s, Sigma, St. Louis, MO, USA) and baked at 75 °C for 30 min.

A schematic of the DMF bottom plate (chip) used in the present study is shown in Fig.
1
. The bottom plate was designed with an array of 14 actuation electrodes (3 mm × 3 mm each) and 6 reservoir electrodes (6 mm × 6 mm each). The reservoir electrodes are for the sample solution, sample solvent, MB suspension, elution solvent, waste, and a collection area for the elution solution. These reservoirs are all connected to the dispensing electrodes (6 mm × 2.7 mm) that bridge the reservoir with the actuation electrode (3 mm × 3 mm). The actuation electrode can hold an ~1 μL volume of a droplet on itself. To facilitate the inter-electrode droplet movements, an interdigitated pattern was used at the actuation electrode boundaries. The inter-electrode gap was 40 μm. As a top plate, an unpatterned indium tin oxide (ITO) glass substrate (Daehan Scientific, Seoul, Korea) was coated with 50 nm of Teflon-AF (2000 rpm, 60 s) and baked at 75 °C for 30 min and at 170 °C for 30 min. These plates were used immediately or stored in a sealed Petri dish prior to use. The DMF device was assembled by joining the top and bottom plates together using two pieces of 3 M Scotch double-sided tape. The total spacing between the two plates was approximately 180 μm.
DMF chip design and the dimensions of the electrodes

Droplet movement was electronically controlled by lab-written software coded using Labview™ (National Instruments, Austin, TX, USA). A series of sequential pairs of AC potentials were applied to the corresponding bottom-plate electrodes to drive a droplet on the DMF chip. A sequence of sine-wave pulses (10 kHz) was generated using a function generator (SG 1634 N, MCP Lab Electronics, Shanghai, China) and amplified to 330–350 V
pp
by a two-channel amplifier (PZD700-2-H-CE-EX, TREK Inc., Lockport, NY, USA). To control a sequence of high-voltage AC potentials onto the electrodes, four 8-channel relay modules (Songle, Yuyao city, Zhejiang, China), which were gated by 96 bidirectional
I
/
O
channels with a 5-V TTL/CMOS capability (National Instruments), were used. Droplet movements were monitored and recorded using a smartphone camera (G3, LG Electronics, Seoul, Korea).

CWA simulants were purified using an SPE method. A CWA simulant mixture solution was prepared in an EA/1-propanol (1:1, v:v) solvent and was allowed to reach room temperature. Initially, a diol-SPE-cartridge was conditioned with 3 mL of ACN and washed with 3 mL of EA/1-propanol (1:1, v:v). Then, 1 mL of the CWA simulant mixture was loaded onto the cartridge by passing the sample solution slowly through the cartridge. Finally, analytes were eluted with 1 mL of ACN.

On-chip SPE purification/enrichment of a mixture of nerve gas simulants was performed using the so-called
supernatant separation
method (Ng et al.
2012
); its procedure is depicted in Fig.
2
. The solutions of the MB suspension (1 mg/mL), sample solvent, sample (nerve gas simulant mixture) solution, and elution solvent were prepared in ACN, EA/1-propanol (1:1, v/v), EA/1-propanol (1:1, v/v), and ACN, respectively. Before droplet actuations, each of these solutions was loaded on the respective reservoir by manual injection from the side using a syringe after the device was assembled.

Description of the four-step DMF SPE processes.
a
Removal of ACN solvent from the MB-containing suspension solution,
b
equilibration of MBs with a new sample solvent,
c
loading of the sample onto the surfaces of the MBs,
d
elution of the desired CWA simulants from the MB surfaces

As shown in Fig.
2
a, a droplet containing diol-functionalized MBs was dispensed from the “bead suspension” reservoir electrode and was transferred to one of the rectangular electrodes (①). A neodymium magnet was positioned beneath the corresponding electrode to focus functionalized MBs into a pellet and to immobilize them. Next, only the ACN supernatant droplet was separated away from this electrode, and the functionalized MBs remained behind in the form of a pellet (②). The ACN supernatant droplet was dumped into the waste reservoir (③). Because ACN and the sample solvent (EA/1-propanol (1:1, v/v)) are not well miscible, the MBs, which were originally suspended in ACN solution, were washed twice with the sample solvent (EA/1-propanol (1:1, v/v)) droplet by circulating the MB-containing droplets around the adjacent electrodes (see ④ and ⑤ in Fig.
2
b). The washing supernatant droplet was separated from the MBs and dumped into the waste reservoir (⑥). In the third step shown in Fig.
2
c, two droplets of the nerve gas simulant mixture were mixed with the diol-functionalized MBs (⑦), and then the resulting droplet was incubated for 10 min. This droplet was agitated (stirred) by circulating around the neighboring electrodes every two minutes (⑧) with the magnet pulled off from the chip. During incubation, some of the analyte molecules were adsorbed onto the surface of the diol-functionalized MBs. After incubation, the supernatant solution was separated from the MBs (⑨). In the final step (Fig.
2
d), the ACN elution droplet was transferred to the electrode where the MBs were located (⑩). The resulting MB-containing droplet was agitated (stirred) three times by circulating the droplet around the neighboring electrodes (⑪). After that, the MB-containing droplet was incubated for 5 min, and then only the supernatant elution solution was separated from the MBs and was moved to the collecting area (reservoir electrode) (⑫). The total sample preparation time on the chip was approximately 30 min. When dealing with the MB-containing droplets, careful attention was paid to the optimization of the concentration of the MBs. When the concentration of the MBs was too high, the MBs tended to stick to the Teflon-AF surface, particularly after the extended holding by the magnet.

For the off-chip analysis, 1 μL of analyte solution, which was pre-mixed with CHCA matrix solution, was loaded onto a MALDI plate (MTP 384 polished steel TF targets; Bruker Daltonics, Leipzig, Germany). The matrix solution was prepared by dissolving 1 mg of CHCA in a 0.1% TFA-containing water/acetonitrile (1:1, v:v) solution. This matrix solution was sonicated for 10 min and was subjected to centrifugation (5000 rpm, 5 min). For the DMF on-chip analysis, 3 μL of sample solution and 3 μL of a matrix solution were mixed, and then 1 μL of the resulting mixed solution was loaded onto the MALDI plate. For both the off-chip and on-chip sample analyses, three sample spots were loaded onto the MALDI plate.

For the MALDI-TOF MS analysis, a MALDI-TOF MS spectrometer from Bruker Daltonics (Autoflex Speed series, Leipzig, Germany) was used in the positive-ion reflectron mode. In the MALDI-TOF instrument, a 355-nm Nd:YAG laser was used as a light source, and its power was carefully adjusted for optimal detection of CWA (nerve gas) simulants. The detection mass widow was set at
m/z
120–230 to efficiently detect the five nerve gas simulants in optimal conditions. For the mass spectrum recording, 2000 MALDI-TOF mass spectra were accumulated. The ion optics setting was as follows: ion source 1 (extraction) voltage, +19.05 kV; ion source 2, +16.70 kV; reflectron voltage, +20.99 kV.

GC-MS experiments were carried out using a Hewlett-Packard GC 6890-MS 5973 system (Palo Alto, CA, USA) with an electron impact (EI) ionization source. The CWA simulant analysis was performed using a capillary column (FFAP, Agilent J&W) with a dimension of 30 m × 0.32 mm I.D. × 0.25 μm phase thickness. The GC-MS system was operated in the splitless mode. Helium gas was used as a carrier gas, and the flow rate was maintained at 1 mL/min. The temperature program parameters were as follows: The initial temperature was set at 60 °C for 10 min and was raised to 240 °C at a rate of 12 °C/min, with a final hold time of 3 min. The EI ionization energy was 70 eV. The mass range was 30–300 a.m.u. (atomic mass unit) in the full-scan mode. Analytes were identified using the Wiley mass spectral library.

The structures of the five CWA (nerve gas) simulants under examination are shown in Scheme
1
. In battle or terror-related situations, the CWAs might be collected in the form of aqueous samples or aqueous extracts of soil samples. To detect and identify the dissolved CWA molecules, it is necessary to purify, extract, and enrich the CWA molecules (Murray and Southard
2002
; Hook et al.
2003
).

To develop a DMF device-based sample preparation method for the identification of CWA (nerve gas) simulant molecules, it is necessary to establish an off-chip analysis experimental procedure. For this purpose, a variety of solid-phase extraction cartridge sorbent materials were tested for purification, enrichment, and extraction. For example, C
18
, HLB, carbographite, and diol sorbents were tested. Among these cartridges, only diol cartridge, which features short alkyl chains with polar functional groups, showed a sufficient binding affinity toward all the CWA simulants examined in this study. The other sorbent materials showed a binding affinity toward only a selected set of simulants. Because the CWA simulants are polar molecules, it is suitable to use diol sorbents that are known to be ideal for the isolation of polar compounds.

The optimized off-chip SPE experimental parameters using the diol cartridge were established as follows. In selecting solvents for sorbent equilibration, MB suspension, and analyte elution from the sorbent material, special caution had to be observed because the solvents used in the off-chip SPE experiments should be compatible with the EWOD principle on the hydrophobic surface. As an equilibration solvent, acetonitrile, which was an MB suspension solvent, was chosen. An EA/1-propanol 1:1 (v:v) solution was found to be suitable as a sample loading solvent. Acetonitrile was again used as an elution solvent.

Figure
3
a shows the MALDI-TOF mass spectra of five CWA (nerve gas) simulants obtained with (upper panel) and without (lower panel) diol solid-phase extraction, in which the amount of each simulant analyzed was 10 nmol; 10 nmol corresponds to DMMP, 414 μg; DPGME, 494 μg; MeSA, 507 μg; TEP, 607 μg; DEP, 741 μg. In the upper panel of Fig.
3
a, all five of the simulants were observed in a form of [M + H]
+
: DMMP,
m/z
125.1; DPGME,
m/z
149.0; MeSA,
m/z
153.1; TEP,
m/z
183.1; DEP,
m/z
223.086. Based on the abundances of the detected peaks, the order of the detection efficiency was found to be TEP > MeSA ~ DMMP ~ DEP > DPGME. In the MALDI-MS analysis, the matrix had to be chosen carefully to avoid overlap between the matrix peaks and the molecular ion peaks of interest. In the present study, the CHCA matrix was found to be the most appropriate matrix to minimize the concerning overlaps (Kim et al.
2016
). Further, the amount of the CHCA matrix in mixing the analytes and matrix was significantly reduced compared with other MALDI experiments to minimize the matrix background peaks. The method detection limits (MDLs) of DPGME, DMMP, TEP, MeSA, and DEP were found to be 13, 12, 15, 15, and 18 μg/mL, respectively. The MDL values were rather high compared with those of the GC-MS experiments (see below).

a
MALDI-TOF mass spectra obtained (
a
) with diol-SPE purification/enrichment (
upper panel
) and without any purification procedure (
lower panel
).
b
MALDI-TOF MS spectra acquired for the CWA simulants prepared through on-chip SPE: mass spectra acquired for 10 nmol, 1 nmol, 100 pmol, and no CWA simulants.
c
Enlarged mass spectra from
b
for DMMP, DPGME, MeSA, TEP, and DEP

The five simulants purified by off-chip diol-SPE were also analyzed using GC-MS. Prior to GC-MS analysis, SPE-treated simulants were vortexed and centrifuged (5000 rpm) for 30 s. Figure
4
a shows the GC-MS chromatogram, in which ten chromatographic peaks were observed (see Table
1
). Among the ten peaks detected, peaks 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, and 7 corresponded to DPGME isomers. The detected six DPGME isomers are likely to be 1-(2-methoxy-1-methylethoxy)-2-propanol, 1-(2-methoxy-2-methylethoxy)-2-propanol, 2-(2-methoxy -1-methylethoxy)-1-propanol, and 2-(2-methoxy-2-methylethoxy)-1-propanol configurational isomers, and two of their diastereomers (see Scheme
2
,
http://www.osha.gov/dts/sltc/methods/organic/org101/org101.html
). Chromatographic peaks 3, 8, 9, and 10, which were detected at 11.5, 14.8, 16.1, and 21.1 min, were identified as DMMP, TEP, MeSA, and DEP, respectively. Separate GC-MS experiments revealed that the off-chip detection limits of DPGME, DMMP, TEP, MeSA, and DEP were 7.4, 2.5, 7.3, 7.6, and 2.0 μg/mL, respectively.

div.p:
DPGME configurational isomers:
A
1-(2-methoxy-1-methylethoxy)-2-propanol (69.3%),
B

For the on-chip washing required to remove the unbound analytes, two different methods can be implemented: “
serial dilution
” and “
supernatant separation
” (Sista et al.
2008a
,
b
; Vergauwe et al.
2011
; Ng et al.
2012
). In previous studies, it was found that the “
supernatant separation
” method was much more efficient in washing and solvent exchange, particularly when droplets without oil were used. In the “
supernatant separation
” method, only the supernatant solution was removed from the MB-containing droplet with the MBs focused and immobilized in a form of a pellet using a magnet (Ng et al.
2012
). In this study, the oil was not used as a suspending medium and therefore
the supernatant separation
method was used. Figure
5
shows a series of video captures in which a supernatant solution was moved from the MB suspension solution electrode to the neighboring empty electrode and orange-colored MBs remained behind.
A series of video captures that show that only the supernatant solution was removed from the MB suspension solution electrode to the neighboring empty electrode and orange-colored MBs remained behind

div.h3: On-chip SPE MALDI-TOF MS and GC-MS analysis
div.p:
The CWA simulants prepared through on-chip SPE were collected and then analyzed using MALDI-TOF MS. Figure
3
b shows MALDI-TOF MS spectra acquired for 10 nmol, 1 nmol, and 100 pmol of CWA simulants; 1 nmol in a 3-μL sample solution corresponds to DMMP, 41.4 μg/mL; DPGME, 49.4 μg/mL; MeSA, 50.7 μg/mL; TEP, 60.7 μg/mL; DEP, 74.1 μg/mL. For comparison, a CHCA matrix-only (no simulant) MALDI-TOF spectrum is also shown. Enlarged mass spectra for DMMP at
m/z
125.1, DPGME at
m/z
149.0, MeSA at
m/z
153.1, TEP at
m/z
183.1, and DEP at
m/z
223.086 are also shown in Fig.
3
c. The MDLs of DMMP, DPGME, MeSA, TEP, and DEP were determined to be 12, 13, 12, 13, and 16 μg/mL, respectively, indicating much higher detection limits compared with those of the on-chip GC-MS (see below). However, it is noteworthy that the MDL values of the on-chip SPE MALDI-TOF MS results are comparable with those of the off-chip SPE MALDI-TOF MS.

In addition, a droplet of the CWA simulants purified and extracted on the DMF device was collected using a syringe and subjected to GC-MS analysis. Figure
4
b shows the GC-MS chromatogram acquired for DPGME (1.5 μg/mL), DMMP (1.2 μg/mL), TEP (1.8 μg/mL), MeSA (1.5 μg/mL), and DEP (2.2 μg/mL). In Fig.
4
b, ten chromatographic peaks were observed, and the identified peaks were identical to those in Fig.
4
a and Table
1
. Among the CWA simulants examined here, DPGME was detected at six different elution times between 11.0 and 13.5 min due to the presence of the different configuration isomers and diastereomers shown in Scheme
2
. Compared to the off-chip SPE GC-MS results, the relative areas of the ten chromatographic peaks shown in Fig.
4
b were almost identical to those of Fig.
4
a, except for peaks 8 (TEP) and 9 (MeSA). The MDLs of the on-chip SPE GC/MS analysis for DPGME, DMMP, TEP, MeSA, and DEP were determined to 2.96, 1.12, 0.018, 0.76, and 0.002 μg/mL, respectively. The MDL of DPGME was higher than those of the other simulants due to the presence of several isomers. The MDLs obtained after the on-chip SPE were significantly lower than those of the off-chip SPE experiments. In separate GC-MS experiments using a headspace SPME (carboxen/polydimethylsiloxane) with 20 min of fiber exposure at 60 °C, the MDLs of DPGME, DMMP, TEP, MeSA, and DEP were determined to 1.59, >1000, 18, 0.15, and 0.02 μg/mL, respectively, suggesting that on-chip SPE efficiency was satisfactory.

The quantitative analysis ability of the DMF-MS methods was validated only for the DMF-GC-MS method. The validation using the MALDI-TOF MS was not performed since MALDI-TOF MS is well known to suffer from the lack of the shot-to-shot, spot-to-spot, and sample-to-sample reproducibility. For the validation of the DMF-GC-MS method, the following characteristics were determined: accuracy, precision, calibration curve performance, and recovery. The validation was performed for five replicates. Accuracy and precision were determined by calculating the percent deviation from the nominal concentration, i.e., relative error (RE), and the coefficient of variation (CV) of replicates, respectively. When these values do not exceed 15%, it is usually acceptable. In the validation, GC-MS measurements were taken right after the DMF extraction experiments in order to minimize the possible evaporation of the CWA simulants. As shown in Table
2
and Supporting information (Table S1-S4), the determined validation results are acceptable in that both accuracy and precision do not exceed 15%, except for the lowest concentration case. Further, the calibration curves showed a good linearity for all five CWA simulants, with all
R
2
values being higher than 0.9900 (see Fig.
6
). The recovery rates for the five CWA simulants were found to be below 5%, which is quite low compared with the conventional analytical methods. The low recovery appears to be due to multiple factors such as evaporation of the analytes, analyte adhesion to the Teflon-AF surfaces, and the low overall capturing efficiency of the diol-MBs arising mainly from the low concentration of MBs; high concentrations of MBs prohibited the facile movements of the MB-containing solution.
